title: 108_s810
content: The Act titled "Protecting Children Against Crime Act of 2003" eliminates the statute of limitations for child abduction and sex crimes, allowing for prosecution at any time for offenses involving minor victims or certain felonies. The Act "Protecting Children Against Crime Act of 2003" removes the statute of limitations for child abduction and sex offenses, allowing prosecution for any offense committed before, on, or after the enactment date. Additionally, the Act amends the registration program for child pornographers in the National Sex Offender Registry. The Act "Protecting Children Against Crime Act of 2003" removes the statute of limitations for child abduction and sex offenses, allowing prosecution for any offense committed before, on, or after the enactment date. It also amends the registration program for child pornographers in the National Sex Offender Registry. In subsection (a)(3), clauses are revised and new provisions are added related to the production or distribution of child pornography. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Department of Justice for fiscal years 2004 through 2007. Additionally, a grant program is established for new technologies to improve AMBER Alert communications plans. The Attorney General of the United States shall provide grants to States for the development or enhancement of programs for AMBER Alert communications plans, including new technologies. The Federal share of funding may not exceed 50%, and grants should be distributed equitably throughout the United States. The Attorney General will administer the program. The Attorney General will prescribe requirements for grants under the program and authorize $5,000,000 for each fiscal year 2004-2007 to the Department of Justice for this purpose. The funds will remain available until expended. The National Research Council will conduct a study and report on online pornography. The National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences will study the detection of illicit child pornography sites on the Internet, the use of credit cards for illegal child pornography sales, credit card issuer systems for identifying purveyors, and options for increasing reporting to law enforcement. A report to Congress is due within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The National Research Council will submit a report to Congress on the study conducted regarding illicit child pornography sites and credit card use for illegal sales within 12 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments remain unaffected.
